examples.en: He isn’t interesting at all. All he talks about is the urban legend of Battleship Island.
examples.ja: アイツはぜんぜん面白くないな。話題といったら軍艦島の都市伝説だけだし。

meaning_mnemonic: A 軍艦 is a <kanji>battleship</kanji>, and 島 is an island. Welcome to... <vocabulary>Battleship Island</vocabulary> (go Jurassic Park music).
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi readings for 軍 and 艦, and the kun'yomi reading for 島. You learned all of them, so you should know the reading already! Oh, but watch out for the rendaku.

examples.en: That guy bragged about his fake Gucci wallet to me.
examples.ja: あの男、俺に偽物のグッチの財布を自慢してきたんだぜ。

examples.en: If you go to Itaewon, you can buy fake branded goods.
examples.ja: イテウォンに行けばブランド物の偽物が買えますよ。

examples.en: We have recently received information that a fake Koichi is living in downtown Portland.
examples.ja: 最近、ポートランドのダウンタウンにコウイチの偽物が住んでいるという情報をキャッチしました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>fake</kanji> <kanji>thing</kanji> is <vocabulary>fake</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>counterfeit</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: You've learned both of these readings already. No fakes there.

examples.en: Is it okay if I open this package at the stroke of midnight?
examples.ja: 日付が変わる瞬間に包みを開けてもいい？

meaning_mnemonic: Something that you <kanji>wrap</kanji> is a <vocabulary>bundle</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>package</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned it when you learned 包む, but here's a reminder of the mnemonic just in case:

Remember how you wrap your <vocabulary>bundle</vocabulary>s? That's right, with the <reading>two two</reading> technique. Your <vocabulary>package</vocabulary>s are always double wrapped.

examples.en: I sincerely apologize.
examples.ja: 誠に申し訳ございません。

examples.en: I really thank you for coming all the way here.
examples.ja: わざわざお越しいただき、誠にありがとうございます。

examples.en: That is indeed wonderful.
examples.ja: それは誠に素晴らしいことだ。

examples.en: I am really sorry, but all rooms in our hotel are non-smoking.
examples.ja: 誠に申し訳ありませんが、当ホテルは全室禁煙となっております。

meaning_mnemonic: The に on the end of this word turns <kanji>sincerity</kanji> into an adverb. What's the adverb version of sincerity? It's <vocabulary>sincerely</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>indeed</vocabulary>. It <vocabulary>really</vocabulary> is.
reading_mnemonic:
This shares the same reading as the vocabulary word 誠, but here's a reminder just in case:

<reading>My coat</reading> (まこと) <vocabulary>really</vocabulary> is a coat! <vocabulary>Indeed</vocabulary>, it is.

examples.en: My boyfriend’s family name is 御手洗, which is an unusual name.
examples.ja: 私の彼氏の苗字は「御手洗」という珍名です。

examples.en: This type of gold fish is a rare variety, and it's 50,000 yen.
examples.ja: この金魚は珍種で、一匹５万円です。

examples.en: Last year, the professor invented a quirky gadget called "automatic dog walker."
examples.ja: 去年、教授は「自動犬散歩マシン」という珍道具を発明しました。

examples.en: Last night they were showing both great and unusual baseball plays on TV.
examples.ja: 昨夜、テレビで野球の名プレーと珍プレーを放送してたよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
Something <kanji>rare</kanji> is often <vocabulary>unusual</vocabulary>. This word could also mean <vocabulary>rare</vocabulary> (of course) and <vocabulary>peculiar</vocabulary> depending on the context.

These days, media often uses this word to describe the way something is unusual, quirky, and funny.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this kanji is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. That in itself isn't too <vocabulary>rare</vocabulary>, wouldn't you say?

examples.en: I have gout and I know I should avoid beer, but I can’t help drinking it today because my friend gave me some delicacies that go well with beer.
examples.ja: 私は痛風なのでビールを飲まない方がいいのは分かっているんですが、友人からビールに良く合う珍味をもらったので今日ばかりは我慢できませんね。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>rare</kanji> <kanji>taste</kanji> is a taste you can't have very often, because it's rare. This is a <vocabulary>delicacy</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: It’s not rare to see bacon on donuts around here.
examples.ja: この辺ではベーコンの乗ったドーナッツはそう珍しいものではありませんよ。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>rare</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>rare</vocabulary>. But, this can also mean <vocabulary>unusual</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>curious</vocabulary> (as in "odd" curious, not that you're curious about something).
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You know what's <vocabulary>unusual</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>rare</vocabulary>? This <reading>maze</reading> is <reading>ra</reading>re (めずら). I don't think there's a way out of it. We've been walking around for days now, and we haven't gotten any closer to the exit!

examples.en: I was jealous of her talent, so I tore the canvas she was painting for an art competition to pieces.
examples.ja: 私は彼女の才能を妬んでおり、彼女が絵画コンクールに向けて絵を描いていたキャンバスを切り裂きました。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>split</kanji>, but if you split something, you are going <vocabulary>to tear</vocabulary> it or <vocabulary>to rip up</vocabulary> it.
reading_mnemonic: In order to get it open, you need <vocabulary>to tear</vocabulary> and rip up a <reading>sack</reading> (さく). Sacks don't have tabs or zippers or any of those fancy things. If you want to get at the stuff in a sack you have to tear the top right off!

examples.en: The two sides couldn't agree and the talks broke down.
examples.ja: 両者の意見が合わず、話し合いは決裂した。

examples.en: What do you think was the cause of the breakdown in the negotiations?
examples.ja: 交渉が決裂した原因は何だと思いますか？

examples.en: The collapse of talks on the verge of an agreement had a significant impact on the stock market.
examples.ja: 合意目前での決裂は株式市場に大きな影響を与えました。

examples.en: That man was, no doubt, eagerly awaiting the breakdown of their relationship from within his jail cell.
examples.ja: あの男は奴らの決裂を、牢屋の中で舌なめずりをしながら待っていたに違いない。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>decision</kanji> is <kanji>split</kanji>, causing a <vocabulary>breakdown</vocabulary> in all we've decided. A big ol' <vocabulary>rupture</vocabulary>.

決裂 is a formal word used when talks or relationships totally fall apart. Since it refers to a full-on rupture and sounds dramatic, you'll often see it in news headlines or news reports when negotiations between companies or countries crash and burn.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I thought the political party was split three ways, but it was actually split four ways.
examples.ja: その政党は三派に分裂したと思っていたんだけど、実際は四派に分裂していたんだね。

meaning_mnemonic:
Things get <kanji>divide</kanji>d and <kanji>split</kanji>. We can just call this a <vocabulary>split</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>division</vocabulary>.

分裂 primarily refers to cells dividing in biology, but it can also figuratively describe an entity or group splitting into separate parts, often due to internal conflict.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I was literally caught with my pants down by a sudden, severe attack from a stomach ache.
examples.ja: 俺は文字通りズボンを下げたところで、突然の激しい腹痛に襲われました。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>attack</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to attack</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "You going <vocabulary>to attack</vocabulary> me or something? <reading>Oh so</reading> scary you are. Oh so scary. Ho ho ho."

examples.en: A police car was attacked by a motorcycle gang.
examples.ja: 警察の車は、暴走族に襲撃された。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>attack</kanji> <kanji>attack</kanji> is an <vocabulary>attack</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>assault</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: We didn’t expect our rival’s surprise attack.
examples.ja: 敵の奇襲を予想できなかった。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>odd</kanji> <kanji>attack</kanji> is an attack you don't expect. This is a <vocabulary>surprise attack</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: When I looked up at the sky, the air raid was just about to happen.
examples.ja: 僕が空を見上げると、ちょうど空襲が始まるところだった。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>sky</kanji> <kanji>attack</kanji> is an <vocabulary>air raid</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>air attack</vocabulary>. Tora tora tora!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Pac-Man counterattacked and started eating the monsters that were chasing him.
examples.ja: パックマンは、追ってくるモンスターを逆襲して食べ始めた。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>reverse</kanji> <kanji>attack</kanji> is a <vocabulary>counterattack</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Why did G20 reject financially contributing to the bailout?
examples.ja: どうしてG20は財政支援への貢献を否認したのですか。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>tribute</kanji> I <kanji>offer</kanji> is my <vocabulary>contribution</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I’ve never seen such a tasteful doggie bag before.
examples.ja: こんなに趣のあるお持ち帰り用の容器を見たのは初めてです。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. 
This word covers a lot of meanings so it can be <vocabulary>charm</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>taste</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>vibe</vocabulary>, or even <vocabulary>gist</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: If something has <vocabulary>charm</vocabulary>, your thought/思 (おも) goes in that direction/向き (むき).  You feel the vibe? Do you get the gist?

examples.en: My hobby is housecleaning.
examples.ja: 私の趣味は家の大掃除です。

meaning_mnemonic: If something's got <kanji>charm</kanji> and is to your <kanji>taste</kanji>, then it's your <vocabulary>hobby</vocabulary>. Hobbies are activities that you find charming and develop a taste for.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Long‐distance flights will be tough for me when I get old.
examples.ja: 年を取ったら長距離のフライトはきつくなるだろうね。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>distance</kanji> that is <kanji>detach</kanji>ed from the distance is the <vocabulary>distance</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>range</vocabulary>. Just think of one part of the distance, stretch it out, and then look at it. It shows the distance and range!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I need an official copy of my family register.
examples.ja: 私は戸籍謄本の写しが必要です。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>door</kanji> <kanji>register</kanji>? Well, a register of people who live behind the same door. In other words, a <vocabulary>family register</vocabulary>. (Think of "door" as shorthand for a house in this case.) Family registers are actually pretty interesting. Look up "koseki" on Google and you're sure to find many fascinating histories.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 戸 is an exception. Instead of と it's こ. Just think about how the person who runs this census doesn't care about number of toes. They care about number of <reading>子</reading> (こ).

examples.en: I don’t have Japanese citizenship, but is it possible for me to take the bar examination?
examples.ja: 日本国籍がないんですが、司法試験を受験することは可能ですか？

meaning_mnemonic: If you're on a <kanji>country</kanji>'s <kanji>register</kanji>, you probably have <vocabulary>nationality</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>citizenship</vocabulary> there. What's your 国籍?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I’m having second thoughts about publishing a tell-all book.
examples.ja: 暴露本の出版については現在再考中です。

meaning_mnemonic:
Using <kanji>violence</kanji> I'm going to <kanji>expose</kanji> the truth! This is <vocabulary>disclosure</vocabulary>. This is <vocabulary>exposure</vocabulary>.

This word carries the connotation of something scandalous being revealed, often in a dramatic manner.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 暴 is strange and new, not what you learned with the kanji. Just think about how when there is disclosure or exposure of something, you are surprised. You can't believe that's the truth. You have to take a step <reading>back</reading> (ばく) to deal with the new information.

examples.en: I was pretty surprised at how blunt she was.
examples.ja: 彼女があまりに露骨にものを言うもので、少々面食らいました。

meaning_mnemonic: I'm going to <kanji>expose</kanji> my <kanji>bone</kanji>s for a second here and be <vocabulary>blunt</vocabulary> with you... this makes sense, because if you're exposing your bones at someone, you're not hiding anything. You're being frank and blunt.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Every accessory I bought from the street stall broke immediately.
examples.ja: あの露店で買ったアクセは全部すぐ壊れちゃったよ。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>expose</kanji>d <kanji>shop</kanji> is one that's not inside. It's outside, and exposed. It's a <vocabulary>street stall</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I thought better of it and refrained from wearing such a revealing dress.
examples.ja: 思い直して、肌の露出が激しいドレスを着るのは控えることにしました。

meaning_mnemonic: When what you <kanji>expose</kanji> is <kanji>exit</kanji>ed out of hiding, exposed for everything to see... that is <vocabulary>exposure</vocabulary>. It can also refer to <vocabulary>photographic exposure</vocabulary> too, in case you were wondering.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Has the pastor already left the church for the day?
examples.ja: 牧師さんはもう今日は教会を出ちゃいましたか？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>pasture</kanji> <kanji>teacher</kanji> is one who leads his flock around through life. This is a <vocabulary>pastor</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>minister</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>clergyman</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: In a few years my father will die and I’ll inherit his ranch.
examples.ja: 二、三年くらいしたら、父親が死んで、俺は父さんの牧野を相続する事になると思うよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>pasture</kanji> <kanji>field</kanji> is <vocabulary>pasture land</vocabulary>. It's also a <vocabulary>ranch</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

The secondary reading is a bit different. That's a family name, and uses the kun'yomi readings of both kanji. We'll consider this secondary for now, but you may have to come back to this when you see this as a name and are all like "what's going on here??"

examples.en: It has been below freezing for days, so all my grass is dead.
examples.ja: 氷点下の日々が続いているせいで、牧草が全てやられてしまった。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>pasture</kanji> <kanji>grass</kanji> is the <vocabulary>pasture</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>grass</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: With 草 you learned a different reading from the one here. Just think about how with this <vocabulary>pasture</vocabulary> you have to constantly <reading>sew</reading> (そう) it together to make it come together, otherwise it comes apart and moves all around, and that's no good for any pasture.

examples.en: This farm boasts a good ice cream shop that uses fresh milk.
examples.ja: この牧場には、絞り立ての牛乳を使った自慢のアイスクリーム屋さんがあるんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>pasture</kanji> <kanji>place</kanji> is a <vocabulary>livestock farm</vocabulary>. It's also a <vocabulary>ranch</vocabulary>. The place where things pasture is this place.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: We should print our advertisements on nice paper with cooking recipes so that people will keep them on their fridge.
examples.ja: 我々の広告を上質の紙に料理のレシピと一緒に印刷すれば、みんなそれを冷蔵庫に貼っておいてくれるんじゃないかな。

meaning_mnemonic: With a <kanji>seal</kanji> we're <kanji>printing</kanji> everything out. The seal is what prints the words on the paper, making this <vocabulary>printing</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: How many New Year’s cards should we print this year?
examples.ja: 今年は年賀状何枚刷ればいいかなあ？

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>printing</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to print</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: When you print something out, it's usually the paperwork needed in order to <reading>sue</reading> (す) someone. You're just that kind of person, always looking to sue.

examples.en: He used to be a cheerful young man.
examples.ja: 彼はかつては明朗快活な青年だった。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>bright</kanji> <kanji>bright</kanji> is something that's <vocabulary>bright</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I’m here to tell you some good news.
examples.ja: 朗報を伝えるためにここに来ました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>bright</kanji> <kanji>news</kanji> report is going to be one full of <vocabulary>good news</vocabulary>. A dark news report is probably bad news, but we only care about good news right now, don't we?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I got an international call from someone I didn’t know with a melodious voice.
examples.ja: 朗らかな声をした知らない人から国際電話がかかってきました。

meaning_mnemonic: This is the na-adjective version of <kanji>bright</kanji>. The word is <vocabulary>bright</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>cheerful</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Of all the people who are bright and cheerful, one man comes to mind. The cheerful Hulk <reading>Hoga</reading>n (ほが).

examples.en: Can’t we find out when the tide rises by looking online?
examples.ja: インターネットで調べたら潮の満ち引きの時刻が分かるんじゃない？

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: If you think of the tide, you think of the ocean. If you think of the ocean and what it's filled with (besides water) you think of <reading>salt</reading> (しお).

examples.en: They brought about a social trend against the rich.
examples.ja: 彼らは、富裕層に反対する社会的風潮を生み出した。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>wind</kanji> <kanji>tide</kanji> is the direction in which the tide is blowing. Is it blowing in? Is it blowing out? It is the <vocabulary>tide</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>current</vocabulary>. These days, we usually use this word for the current <vocabulary>trend</vocabulary>s that come in like the tide.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Is high tide the best time to go fishing?
examples.ja: 一番釣りに適しているのは満潮時でしょうか？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>full</kanji> <kanji>tide</kanji> is a <vocabulary>high tide</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>full tide</vocabulary>. That's when the water comes up.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: It’s not easy to row against the rough tide, but that’s the only way for us to get back to our cottage.
examples.ja: 荒い潮流に逆らってボートを漕ぐのは簡単ではないが、コテージに戻るにはそれしか方法がない。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>tide</kanji>s <kanji>stream</kanji> is the stream going through the tide. It's the <vocabulary>tide</vocabulary> or the <vocabulary>tidal current</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I found a super cute teddy bear and immediately bought it.
examples.ja: すごく可愛いテディーベアを見つけたので、即買いしちゃいました。

meaning_mnemonic: If you see 即 before a word, you know that it's probably something that happens really fast or instantaneously. That's why this is <vocabulary>immediate</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>instant</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Everyone told him that his impromptu poem was great, but it was obviously just lip service.
examples.ja: みんなは彼が即興で作った詩をすごいねと褒めたが、口先だけなのは見え見えでした。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>instant</kanji> <kanji>interest</kanji> in something you didn't have interest in before? Well, time for some <vocabulary>improvisation</vocabulary>, because you're going to have to pretend you have interest in it (since you don't actually).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the shortening of そく.

examples.en: Please don’t expect immediate results.
examples.ja: 即座の結果は期待しないでください。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>instant</kanji> <kanji>sit</kanji> is <vocabulary>immediate</vocabulary>. It's also <vocabulary>instantaneous</vocabulary>. Just imagine yourself sitting instantly. No time passes between when you were standing and sitting. The instantaneous nature of your sit is definitely... troubling.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: He tried to ride tidal bore and surf it, but unfortunately he died instantly.
examples.ja: 彼は潮津波に乗ってサーフィンをしようとしたが、残念ながら即死した。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>instant</kanji> <kanji>death</kanji> is an <vocabulary>instant death</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: We send out this rotisserie on the same day as you order.
examples.ja: この回転肉焼き器は、注文日の即日に発送致します。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>instant</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji> is the day that's going on this instant. It's the <vocabulary>same day</vocabulary> as now.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 即 is the normal one. For 日 you're going to want to use the じつ reading, because, the <reading>truth</reading> (じつ) is that it's the same day today.

examples.en: I’ll show you a way to instantly remove eye strain.
examples.ja: 即効で目の疲れを取る方法をお教えしましょう。

meaning_mnemonic: It's <kanji>instant</kanji>ly <kanji>effect</kanji>ive! Sounds like something out of Pokemon. This word means <vocabulary>immediate effect</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>instant effect</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the shortening.

examples.en: The girl built a wall around her heart.
examples.ja: 少女は心に垣をめぐらせていた。

examples.en: It was necessary to build a hedge to prevent wild animals from destroying the fields.
examples.ja: 野生動物に畑を荒らされないように垣を造る必要があった。

examples.en: A strong fence of stone and wood was built around the castle.
examples.ja: 城の周りに石や木で強固な垣が築かれた。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

Note that for the word fence in Japanese, フェンス is typically used. 垣 isn't very common but it's sometimes used in literature.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: The man placed his prosthetic hand gently on the hedge.
examples.ja: 男は垣根の上にそっと義手を置きました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>hedge</kanji> (or <kanji>fence</kanji>) <kanji>root</kanji> is where the hedge and fence grow from. What grows from this? Well, it's simply a <vocabulary>hedge</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>fence</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. With 垣 that's the one you learned and with 根 that's the vocab version of the kanji.

examples.en: He couldn’t climb over the stone wall because he has artificial legs.
examples.ja: 彼は義足を付けていたので、石垣を乗り越えられませんでした。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>stone</kanji> <kanji>hedge</kanji> is a wall (hedges are nice walls), but it's made of stone. It's a <vocabulary>stone wall</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the readings for 石 and 垣 combined into one word. Be careful of the rendakus.

examples.en: He's awfully persistent as he still clings to his faded glory even though he lost his authority.
examples.ja: 権威を失ったのにまだ過去の栄光にしがみついていて、全く往生際が悪いったらありゃしないよ。

meaning_mnemonic: You have <kanji>rights</kanji> and <kanji>might</kanji> over this area. That gives you <vocabulary>authority</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Kenichi acts like the top dog of the company and he's being really arrogant.
examples.ja: ケンイチは会社のトップのような顔をして威張ってる。

meaning_mnemonic: Take your <kanji>dignity</kanji> and <kanji>stretch</kanji> it. Your dignity is so stretched! That makes you feel big! That's why this word is <vocabulary>to act big</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be arrogant</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading is from 威 and 張る. Just watch out for the rendaku that changes the 張る reading to ばる. Here's a little mnemonic to help with that:

If you're trying <vocabulary>to act big</vocabulary>, you should shout <reading>baa</reading> (ば) at people like a sheep. Why? Because sheep are known <vocabulary>to be arrogant</vocabulary>. Their "baa" is like an arrogant little laugh, don't you think? Baa, baa! That's why it's good to copy them and say "baa" when you want to act big and push people around.

examples.en: As we get closer to spring and the arrival of baseball season, that pitcher's stuff has been getting stronger and stronger.
examples.ja: 野球のシーズンが到来する春に近づくにつれて、あの投手の球威は益々増しています。

meaning_mnemonic:
Your <kanji>sphere</kanji> <kanji>might</kanji> is the force you command over a sphere or ball… in this case, a baseball, making this <vocabulary>a pitcher's stuff</vocabulary>. 

If you're not familiar with this baseball term, we recommend giving it a google. In short, it refers to a pitcher's pitches, judged by how inherently hard those pitches are to hit.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The king's words had authority.
examples.ja: 王の言葉には威厳があった。

examples.en: He said that with dignity.
examples.ja: 彼はそれを威厳をもって言いました。

examples.en: The principal spoke to the graduates with dignity.
examples.ja: 校長は威厳をもって卒業生に語りかけた。

examples.en: The quiet mountains before dawn possess a majesty so great it leaves you speechless.
examples.ja: 夜明け前の静かな山には、言葉を失うほどの威厳がある。

examples.en: Even now, my grandfather's portrait gives off a sense of dignity.
examples.ja: 祖父の遺影からは、今でも威厳が感じられる。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Dignity</kanji> is a <kanji>strict</kanji> thing. If you're too lenient, you'll lose all your <vocabulary>dignity</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>majesty</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I know I was just a 6-year-old kid, but I got so mad when my dad opened the envelope and read the letter from my friend without asking me first.
examples.ja: 自分が六歳の子どもだってことは分かってたけど、父さんが勝手に封を開けて友達からの手紙を読んだことにはすごく腹が立ったわ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji is <kanji>seal in</kanji>, but the vocab noun version is <vocabulary>seal</vocabulary>. This is simply a seal (not the water kind, the kind you use to seal something with).
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as one of the readings you learned: ふう. Don't be a <reading>foo</reading>l, make sure you seal your envelopes.

examples.en: It says I can return unopened products at any time, but what if I opened it and the stuff inside was broken or I didn’t like it?
examples.ja: 開封前の商品であればいつでも返品可って書いてあるけど、開封後に中身が壊れてたり、その商品が好きじゃなかった場合はどうなんだろう。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you <kanji>open</kanji> something <kanji>seal</kanji>ed, you're <vocabulary>unsealing</vocabulary> it or <vocabulary>breaking a seal</vocabulary>.

開封 generally refers to opening something sealed, like opening a letter or package.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I signed the contract and put it in an envelope, but I haven’t mailed the sealed letter to them yet.
examples.ja: 契約書にサインをして封筒に入れてありますが、まだその封書を郵送していません。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>seal in</kanji> <kanji>writing</kanji> is writing that has been sealed into an envelope. This is a <vocabulary>sealed letter</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Today we learned about feudalism in history class.
examples.ja: 今日は歴史の授業で封建主義について学びました。

meaning_mnemonic: You've learned that 主義 is "-ism." So what happens when you <kanji>seal</kanji> up everything you <kanji>build</kanji> and keep it for yourself, and make that your -ism? You get <vocabulary>feudalism</vocabulary>. Why? Because feudalism is a system built on the idea that power should be sealed within one group or family. Anyone outside of this sealed system is a vassal to the lord — that's feudalism for you.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't seen the ほう reading for 封 yet though, so here's a mnemonic to help you out:

Everything belonged to a feudal lord under <vocabulary>feudalism</vocabulary>, even your <reading>ho</reading>me (ほう). People didn't have private property in those days, so you could only live in a home if a feudal lord gave you permission to. I guess, in a way, that means under feudalism you were always sharing your home. With a feudal lord. Aww, how nice!

examples.en: We divvied up the money and put your share in the envelope.
examples.ja: 金はきっちり人数分に山分けして、お前の取り分はその封筒に入れておいたぜ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Seal in</kanji> the <kanji>cylinder</kanji>. This cylinder that is sealed in is an <vocabulary>envelope</vocabulary>. You just have to think back to the day, when things were more like in scroll form. So, a scroll's envelope would have been shaped like a cylinder, making this an <vocabulary>envelope</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Can you put the thermometer back in its tube when you’re done using it?
examples.ja: 使い終わったら、体温計を筒の中に戻しておいてね。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. You'll see this used to mean <vocabulary>pipe</vocabulary> more often than <vocabulary>cylinder</vocabulary>, though.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: When it comes to <vocabulary>pipe</vocabulary>s, you always want to have two sets of two of them, just in case. So, that's a <reading>two two</reading> (つつ) set of pipes, lined up next to each other for backup.

examples.en: Do I have to declare the consolation money I receive from an insurance company to the revenue office?
examples.ja: 保険会社から受け取る慰謝料は、税務署に申告する必要がありますか。

meaning_mnemonic: I show my <kanji>consolation</kanji> by <kanji>apologiz</kanji>ing. This is <vocabulary>consolation</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Our dog consoles us whenever we get depressed.
examples.ja: 落ち込んでいると、いつもうちのワン子が慰めてくれます。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>consolation</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to console</vocabulary>.

慰める means <vocabulary>to comfort</vocabulary> someone who's experiencing sadness or distress. It can also imply cheering someone up by offering kind words, encouragement, or emotional support.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: I'm going <vocabulary>to console</vocabulary> you for what happened to you. The <reading>nag saw</reading> (なぐさ) was turned on and buzzed through your leg. What a nagging feeling. You need some consoling.

examples.en: We visit a nursing home with therapy dogs every Sunday.
examples.ja: 私達は毎週日曜日、セラピー犬たちと一緒に老人ホームを慰問します。

meaning_mnemonic:
The best <kanji>consolation</kanji> for someone's <kanji>problem</kanji> is <vocabulary>paying a sympathy call</vocabulary>. It is <vocabulary>consolation</vocabulary> through a <vocabulary>sympathy visit</vocabulary>.

慰問 is a formal way of saying お見舞い (sympathy visit). It's often used when someone notable, like a celebrity or politician, makes a visit to offer support and comfort to people in difficult situations, like hospital patients, nursing home residents, or those affected by disasters.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Our company has a mandatory recreation trip every year.
examples.ja: うちの会社では、毎年強制参加の慰安旅行があります。

meaning_mnemonic: You have <kanji>consolation</kanji> so now you can <kanji>relax</kanji>. What a great feeling this is. You now have <vocabulary>solace</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>relaxation</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I’ve been close to that lawyer for decades.
examples.ja: その弁護士さんとはもう何十年も懇意にしていましてね。

meaning_mnemonic:
Being <kanji>courteous</kanji> is the right <kanji>idea</kanji> if you want to be on <vocabulary>friendly</vocabulary> terms with others. The more courteous you are to someone (and vice versa), the more a sense of <vocabulary>closeness</vocabulary> grows between you.

懇意 formally describes being on good, cordial terms with someone. You might talk about a colleague you've become friendly with (懇意になった同僚) or a professor who treats you warmly (懇意にしてくれる教授), for example.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: We are holding a friendly get together for the apartment residents on October 22.
examples.ja: 来る10月22日に、マンションの住人の皆様との懇話会を予定しております。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>courteous</kanji> <kanji>talk</kanji> is a <vocabulary>friendly talk</vocabulary>. We all know that "friendly talks" are never what they seem, though... right?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Through all-you-can-drink parties, I built camaraderie with my teammates.
examples.ja: 飲み放題のパーティーを通じてチームメイトとの懇親を深めました。

examples.en: There will be a friendly mixer for college professors and students at this venue.
examples.ja: この会場で大学の教授や生徒たちの懇親会が行われる予定です。

examples.en: The purpose of this party is to get to know each other better by having a meal and playing games together.
examples.ja: このパーティは一緒に食事やゲームをすることで、懇親を図るのが目的です。

meaning_mnemonic:
If you treat someone with <kanji>courteous</kanji> <kanji>intimacy</kanji>, you're probably trying to build a <vocabulary>friendship</vocabulary> with them. Or… maybe something more? No, stop, it's not that kind of intimacy! This word is all about polite friendship and <vocabulary>camaraderie</vocabulary>. Yay for friendship!

懇親 is a formal word that means getting to know someone better in a friendly and sociable manner. You'll most often see it in the word 懇親会 (a casual party for socializing).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Last week, the mayor had informal talks with people of various professions.
examples.ja: 先週、市長は色々な職業の人々との懇談を行いました。

examples.en: After this class, there will be a parent-teacher meeting.
examples.ja: この授業の後、懇談会があります。

examples.en: There was a flyer for "a roundtable meeting to think about our children's future" in my mailbox.
examples.ja: 家のポストに「こども達の未来を考える懇談会」のチラシが入っていた。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>courteous</kanji> <kanji>talk</kanji> is an <vocabulary>informal talk</vocabulary> where people gather and discuss something in a friendly way.

懇談 is often used for parent-teacher meetings or community meetings. It's an informal but courteous talk, usually between acquaintances rather than close friends.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: You got turned down by her three times already and you still haven’t learned, have you?
examples.ja: 彼女に三度も振られてるっていうのに、お前まだ懲りてないのか。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji means <kanji>chastise</kanji> but the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to learn by experience</vocabulary>. I guess these are kind of similar. When you make a mistake, someone will chastise you, and then you will learn by experience (either via the experience or via the chastising).
reading_mnemonic: As a <reading>child</reading> (こ) you got a lot of chastising, I bet. A lot of learning by experience (of chastising).

examples.en: Violators will receive punishment.
examples.ja: 違反者には懲罰が与えられる。

meaning_mnemonic: I will <kanji>chastise</kanji> you and give you <kanji>penalty</kanji>. I do this as a <vocabulary>discipline</vocabulary>. A <vocabulary>punishment</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Does friction cause static electricity?
examples.ja: 摩擦によって静電気が生じるんですか？

meaning_mnemonic: Things that <kanji>chafe</kanji> and <kanji>rub</kanji> have lots of <vocabulary>friction</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Do you want to drink some beer and watch sumo wrestling tonight?
examples.ja: 今夜ビールを飲みながら相撲を見るってのはどうだい？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>mutual</kanji> <kanji>slap</kanji> is when two big guys run at each other and slap each other. This is <vocabulary>sumo wrestling</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is pretty weird, and not one you've learned. But, you know what sumo is, right? It's just the same as that. It's <reading>すもう</reading>.

examples.en: The students looked at the thermometer simultaneously.
examples.ja: 生徒達は一斉に温度計に目をやりました。

meaning_mnemonic: At <kanji>one</kanji> moment it happened <kanji>simultaneous</kanji>ly. It was <vocabulary>simultaneous</vocabulary>. It was <vocabulary>all at once</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the shortening of 一.

examples.en: I found a really delicious okonomiyaki restaurant, wanna go with me next time?
examples.ja: めっちゃ旨いお好み焼きの店見つけたから、今度一緒に行かへん？

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>delicious</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>delicious</vocabulary>. It also means "<vocabulary>skillful</vocabulary>" and "<vocabulary>clever</vocabulary>" as well, because delicious things are skillfully delicious, right?
reading_mnemonic: What's especially delicious? <reading>Horse</reading> (うま) is delicious. Mmm, that delicious horse.

examples.en: I explained the gist of our family policy to the teacher and how my husband and I don't want to let our kid read such comic books.
examples.ja: 先生には、家庭の方針として、主人と私は子どもにそうした漫画は読ませたくないと思っているという旨を伝えました。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>point</kanji> of something is the <vocabulary>gist</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>principle</vocabulary> of it. So, what's the gist of this vocab word? It's <vocabulary>gist</vocabulary> as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the word 胸 (chest). So, the gist of your body is your chest (it's at the center, and holds everything together, right?). That's why these words are both read as <reading>むね</reading>.

examples.en: I think it would be a plus to understand the fundamentals of the book before the lesson.
examples.ja: 授業前にその本の要旨を理解しておくと、プラスになると思うよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The parts we <kanji>need</kanji>. The <kanji>point</kanji> of that. That is the <vocabulary>main point</vocabulary>. That is the <vocabulary>essentials</vocabulary>. It's what we need and it's to the point, you know?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I got frustrated because the point of his story was very vague.
examples.ja: 彼の話の論旨があまりに不明瞭だったので、苛々しました。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>point</kanji> to my <kanji>theory</kanji> is the <vocabulary>point of an argument</vocabulary>. That's what I'm trying to say in my theory / argument, man!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The cushion on this chair is soft.
examples.ja: このイスはクッションが柔らかい。

examples.en: The sunlight is soft and pleasant.
examples.ja: 日差しが柔らかくて気持ちいい。

examples.en: Hearing his gentle singing voice, her expression softened unconsciously.
examples.ja: 彼の柔らかい歌声に、思わず彼女の表情が柔らかくなった。

meaning_mnemonic:
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, which tells you it's probably an adjective. The kanji means <kanji>gentle</kanji>, and the adjective version means <vocabulary>soft</vocabulary> — as in a gentle, <vocabulary>tender</vocabulary> kind of softness. Think soft towel, soft hand, soft voice… anything soft in a way that gives you the warm fuzzies.

In reference to the human body, 柔らかい can also mean <vocabulary>flexible</vocabulary>, with an emphasis on supple, effortless movement.
reading_mnemonic: You find something that is so <vocabulary>soft</vocabulary> to the touch. You touch it. You can't stop. The monkey you're touching tells you to stop. It doesn't like to be touched. But, you won't stop. "<reading>Yah wha</reading>t (やわ) you gonna do about it, monkey?" "<reading>Yah, wha</reading>t can I do, I guess," replies the monkey.

examples.en: If you don’t know what Judo is, here is a book with a very brief introduction of it.
examples.ja: もし柔道が何かを知らないって言うなら、ここに超簡単な入門書があるよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>gentle</kanji> <kanji>path</kanji> is, surprisingly, <vocabulary>judo</vocabulary>. Yep, the sport / art based on throwing people around.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: That gentle looking barber over there is actually this area’s pimp boss.
examples.ja: あそこで柔和な笑みを浮かべている理髪師は、実はこの辺りのポン引き男どもの親分なんだ。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>gentle</kanji> and <kanji>peace</kanji>ful person is <vocabulary>gentle</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>tender</vocabulary>.

柔和 is commonly used in literature to describe someone whose nature or features express <vocabulary>gentleness</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: You didn't learn this reading of 柔 with the kanji, so let's remember it a different way. You have to be <vocabulary>gentle</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>tender</vocabulary> if you want to touch something that's <reading>new</reading> (にゅう) to this world... a puppy, a kitty, a baby, etc. Anything new needs that <vocabulary>gentleness</vocabulary>.

examples.en: The ship slowly sank into the sea.
examples.ja: 船はゆっくりと海に沈んでいった。

examples.en: When the sun set, lights came on in the city.
examples.ja: 夕日が沈むと、街に明かりがともった。

examples.en: You look a bit depressed. What's on your mind?
examples.ja: なんだか沈んだ顔をしているけど、何を思い詰めてるの？

examples.en: Watching the foam sink in my latte, I thought, "That's kinda how life is."
examples.ja: カフェラテの泡が沈んでいくのを見て、人生みたいだなと思った。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>sink</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to sink</vocabulary>.

On a literal level, 沈む refers to physical sinking — a boat sinking into the water or someone's foot sinking into the mud, for example. However, it can also be used metaphorically to talk about things like the sun setting (太陽が沈む), a nation falling into decline (国が沈む), or even someone "sinking" into a depressed mood (気分が沈む).
reading_mnemonic: Your boat is about <vocabulary>to sink</vocabulary>, so you run around yelling, "<reading>She's</reading> (しず) sinking! She's… she's sinking! Abandon ship!" Boats are always female, so be careful not to say "it." If you don't say "she's" sinking, your crew might not get the message.

examples.en: A lot of laborers were laid off due to business stagnation.
examples.ja: 景気の沈滞により、たくさんの労働者が首を切られました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Sink</kanji> and <kanji>stagnate</kanji>. Imagine something is doing just that. It is in the state of <vocabulary>stagnation</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>inactivity</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Have you ever walked barefoot through a marshy rice paddy?
examples.ja: 沼田を裸足で歩いたことはありますか。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>bog</kanji> <kanji>rice paddy</kanji> is a <vocabulary>marshy rice field</vocabulary>. This is just a rice paddy in marshy form.

In modern language, 沼田 is mostly used as a place name or surname, such as <vocabulary>Numata</vocabulary> City in Gunma Prefecture or someone with the last name Numata.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: This plant with yellow flowers lives in swamps.
examples.ja: この黄色い花を咲かせる植物は、沼沢地に生息します。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>bog</kanji> <kanji>swamp</kanji> is a <vocabulary>swamp</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>marsh</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Oddly, this is the one word that uses the on'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. To remember this particular <vocabulary>swamp</vocabulary>, note how there are two kanji in here that make this area particularly swampy. Because it's the swampiest, boggiest place in all of Japan, of course the <reading>Sho</reading>gun (しょう) wants it for himself. Even though it's useless land, he wants the best of everything, being the Shogun and all.

examples.en: Who would want to believe that horrible family would have eternal peace?
examples.ja: あの忌まわしい家族が未来永劫安泰でいられるなんて、誰が信じたいと思う？

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Relax</kanji> in <kanji>peace</kanji>. Wherever you are that's allowing you to do this, it is certainly <vocabulary>peace</vocabulary>. You feel <vocabulary>security</vocabulary> too.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: They are trying to ruin Japan by manipulating information.
examples.ja: 奴らはメディアで情報操作を行って、日本を滅ぼそうとしているんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>destroy</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to destroy</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>to annihilate</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: You are going <vocabulary>to destroy</vocabulary> the <reading>hoe roe</reading>. This is the roe that comes from the hoe tools. If they create too much roe, they will create too many hoes. And if there are too many hoes, bad things will happen.

examples.en: If the super volcano erupted, we would not be able to escape destruction.
examples.ja: もしその超巨大火山が噴火をすれば、我々は滅亡を免れないだろう。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Destroy</kanji> to <kanji>death</kanji>. If you are destroyed to this point, this will be your <vocabulary>downfall</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>ruin</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: We all support the eradication of drunk driving.
examples.ja: 私達はみんな、飲酒運転撲滅運動をサポートしています。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Slap</kanji> that bug and <kanji>destroy</kanji> it. Haha! I slapped all the bugs away. This is <vocabulary>extermination</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Not all species of whales are endangered.
examples.ja: 全ての種の鯨が絶滅の危機に瀕している訳ではない。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Extinction</kanji> where everything is <kanji>destroy</kanji>ed is <vocabulary>extinction</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The city was annihilated by the atomic bomb.
examples.ja: その都市は原爆により壊滅しました。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>break</kanji> and <kanji>destroy</kanji> something, that is <vocabulary>destruction</vocabulary>. That is <vocabulary>annihilation</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I saw my boyfriend taking a piss in the street and I was completely disillusioned.
examples.ja: 彼氏が道端で立ちションしてるのを見ちゃってさ。もう、完璧に幻滅した。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>illusion</kanji> is <kanji>destroy</kanji>ed. If your illusion is destroyed, that is <vocabulary>disillusionment</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: When you get a cold, eat nourishing food like soy beans or apples.
examples.ja: 風邪を引いたら、大豆だとか林檎だとか、滋養のある物を食べなさい。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Nourishing</kanji> and <kanji>foster</kanji>ing. The thing that gives you this is <vocabulary>nourishment</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>nutrition</vocabulary>.

滋養 is a formal and somewhat old-fashioned word. It's mostly used in writing to describe nutritious foods or the health benefits of supplements, tonics, or energy drinks.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I read in the newspaper this morning that the steel company is planning to build the world’s largest blast furnace.
examples.ja: 今朝の朝刊で、その鉄鋼会社は世界一大きな高炉の建設を計画していると読んだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>high</kanji> <kanji>furnace</kanji> is one that's particularly hot and blasty. This is a <vocabulary>blast furnace</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: My son peed his pants and I washed them, so they’re hanging in front of the fireplace to dry now.
examples.ja: うちの子がおしっこ漏らしをしちゃって、ズボンを洗ったから、今それを暖炉の前で乾かしているのよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>warm</kanji> <kanji>furnace</kanji> is a furnace for warming you and other things. This is a <vocabulary>fireplace</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>hearth</vocabulary> or even a <vocabulary>stove</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Why did they try to hide that the core of the nuclear reactor had melted?
examples.ja: どうして奴らは原子炉の炉心が溶解してしまったことを隠そうとしたんだ？

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>furnace</kanji> <kanji>heart</kanji> is the heart of the furnace. The heart of this particular furnace, the one we're talking about here, is the <vocabulary>nuclear reactor core</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Some people warned the government against building nuclear reactors.
examples.ja: 原子炉の建設について、政府に忠告をした人もいました。

meaning_mnemonic: If a 原子 is an <kanji>atom</kanji> and a 炉 is a <kanji>furnace</kanji>, what is a furnace that has atoms? It is an <vocabulary>atomic reactor</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>nuclear reactor</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: If you’re stingy now and you buy a cheap koto, you’ll probably end up wanting a better one later on.
examples.ja: 今けちって安い琴を買っても、どうせ後から質のいい方が欲しくなるんだから。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>harp</kanji>, at least in Japan, is the <vocabulary>koto</vocabulary>, also known (to us) as the <vocabulary>Japanese harp</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>Japanese zither</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: Could I inquire about your blog's URL, please?
examples.ja: あなたのブログのURLをお伺いしてもよろしいですか？

meaning_mnemonic: If 伺う is "to inquire" or "to visit" then the noun version would be a polite way to say <vocabulary>inquiry</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>enquiry</vocabulary>. In other words, a <vocabulary>question</vocabulary>. It can also mean a <vocabulary>visit</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 伺う.

examples.en: We were surprised that fans had gathered to wait for us when we arrived at the airport.
examples.ja: 空港に到着するとファンが群がっていて、驚きましたよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember 群れる, which means "to flock" or "to crowd."? This also means that!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is a little different from 群れる, though. There's an extra ら in there. That being said, it's pretty similar, so you should be able to use one to remember the other after a few reps. You can also think about it this way: Everyone is flocking together in one place. Strange thing is, it's to a small <reading>村</reading> (むら). There's a 村 reunion going on, that's why.

examples.en: I saw a mole going underground.
examples.ja: モグラが土の下に潜って行くところを見ました。

examples.en: How long can you stay underwater?
examples.ja: 水の中にどのぐらいの間潜っていられますか。

examples.en: My dog learned a trick to jump through a hula hoop.
examples.ja: うちの犬は、フラフープをジャンプして潜る技を身につけました。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>conceal</kanji>, but as a verb, this word means <vocabulary>to go under</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to pass through</vocabulary>. Most commonly, this word means <vocabulary>to dive underwater</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to go underground</vocabulary>. Can you see why the kanji for conceal kind of makes sense in these cases? If you're underwater or underground, no one can see you!
reading_mnemonic:
潜る has two possible readings: もぐる and くぐる. The first is used when you mean to dive underwater or go underground.  The second is used when you pass through or under something, sometimes with difficulty, such as crawling under a fence. We want you to focus on もぐる, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Why are you trying to dive underwater again and again? It's to get <reading>mo' goo</reading> (もぐ) to sell on the black goo market. Who knew that sea goo was such a commodity?

examples.en: The lighter I threw hit the TV and cracked the LCD screen.
examples.ja: 俺の投げたライターがテレビに当たって、液晶画面にヒビが入りました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>fluid</kanji> <kanji>crystal</kanji> is a <vocabulary>liquid crystal</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: This crystal comes in three sizes; small, medium, and large.
examples.ja: この水晶は大中小の三つの大きさがあります。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>water</kanji> <kanji>crystal</kanji> is just a <vocabulary>crystal</vocabulary>. I guess crystals are clear and look kind of like water, yeah? That's why it's being referred to as a water crystal, making it really just a crystal.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: There are a lot of ramen carts standing in a row here.
examples.ja: ここには多くのラーメン屋台が軒を連ねています。

meaning_mnemonic: In order to use a <kanji>house counter</kanji> in the first place, you need to have something to count. That's why you have to find <vocabulary>eaves</vocabulary>. And all those eaves together <vocabulary>stand in a row</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: 

These houses that <vocabulary>stand in a row</vocabulary> are neat and fun to count, but you can't go in because you have <reading>no key</reading> (のき). With no key, those <vocabulary>eaves</vocabulary> are just there for you to look at.

examples.en: They're threatening us to send compensation.
examples.ja: 慰謝料をよこせと脅されています。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 慰謝 means "consolation?" Add <kanji>fee</kanji> to that and you get <vocabulary>compensation</vocabulary>. Or <vocabulary>consolation money</vocabulary>, depending on the situation.

慰謝料 refers to compensation for mental or emotional distress. It covers damages for non-physical harm, such as emotional pain in divorce settlements, affairs, or accidents, where the victim seeks financial redress for their distress.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I’m collecting dew that’s on the leaves.
examples.ja: 葉っぱの上に乗っている露を集めているんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
This word uses the kun'yomi reading of the kanji, but you haven't learned it yet. Here's a mnemonic to help you:

<vocabulary>Dew</vocabulary> is just the earth's way of giving water <reading>to you</reading> (つゆ). Rain is too forceful, you may not go to the ocean or a lake, so the earth gives dew to you by putting it on the grass outside your house everyday!

examples.en: Why did you put the talisman here?
examples.ja: どうしてここに御札をはっているんですか？

examples.en: This is an amulet that I got from the shrine in my hometown.
examples.ja: これは、地元の神社でもらった御札です。

examples.en: Are there talismans in English-speaking countries, too?
examples.ja: 英語圏の国にも、御札ってあるんですか？

meaning_mnemonic: You learned another vocabulary word 札 as "amulet," but this is a special <kanji>honorable</kanji> <vocabulary>amulet</vocabulary>. It's a <vocabulary>talisman</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for the 御 is お because ふだ uses the kun'yomi reading. Kun'yomi + kun'yomi = yes.

examples.en: Are you saying I farted? That's a baseless accusation.
examples.ja: 僕がおならしたって？そんなの濡れ衣だよ。

examples.en: Koichi accused me of something he was responsible for.
examples.ja: コウイチに濡れ衣を被せられた。

examples.en: The only one who believed that it was a false accusation was my dog.
examples.ja: 濡れ衣だったと信じてくれたのは、飼い犬だけだった。

meaning_mnemonic: Ah yes, <kanji>wet</kanji> <kanji>clothes</kanji> must be wet clothes-NOT! This used to mean "wet clothes" a long, long time ago, but these days it's used for <vocabulary>false accusations</vocabulary>. Think of it this way: if you make false, baseless accusations, it's like you're dumping water all over someone for no reason.
reading_mnemonic: This word is made up of the reading from 濡れる and the rendaku version of the きぬ reading of 衣. You learned this reading in the 衣 vocabulary, but here's a mnemonic to remember it. Imagine someone's dumped water on you and you're all wet. You might say "<reading>gi</reading>ve <reading>new</reading> (ぎぬ) clothes to me!"

examples.en: Vietnamese coffee was very sweet. I was surprised!
examples.ja: ベトナムのコーヒー、凄く甘くて驚きました。

examples.en: The teacher's health condition got awfully bad today, so class was canceled.
examples.ja: 今日は、先生の気分が凄く悪くなったため授業が中止になった。

examples.en: I want these rain boots so bad. Do you think ordering them from Amazon Prime Now is worth it?
examples.ja: この長靴が凄く欲しいんだけど、Amazon Prime Nowでオーダーする価値あるかな？

meaning_mnemonic: This may look like a verb at first, but it's actually the adverb version of the adjective 凄い. When something is <kanji>awful</kanji> it's usually <vocabulary>awfully</vocabulary> awful.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You've learned this reading already, so you should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: The fried chicken (karaage) is fried up!
examples.ja: 唐揚げ揚がったよ！

examples.en: We waited quietly until the tempura was deep fried.
examples.ja: 天ぷらが揚がるまで静かに待っていた。

examples.en: We'll head out once the flag is up.
examples.ja: 旗が揚がったら出発だ。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

This is an intransitive verb. The kanji means <kanji>hoist</kanji>, but the verb most commonly means <vocabulary>to be fried up</vocabulary>, ready to eat. Imagine something being hoisted up onto the table because it's fried and ready to eat. The verb can also mean, more logically, <vocabulary>to be up</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.

Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 揚げる.
